linkTarget.anchoringText: Located in the southern region of Argentina, a large area known as Patagonia comprises three productive hydrocarbon basins, which include the Neuquina (NQN), Golfo San Jorge (GSJ), and Austral (AUT) basins (Fig. 1). The water sources for human use and consumption in Patagonia are rivers and lakes, which are fed by waters traveling from the mountain-chain melting sector; in the same way, this water supply is obtained from phreatic (groundwater) levels. As a clear example, the first hydrocarbon discovery in Argentina was during the search for water for human consumption in Comodoro Rivadavia (GSJ), in which oil was found by chance at a depth of 540 m in December of 1907.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Map of the five hydrocarbon-producing basins discussed; indication of the case history location.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the five hydrocarbon-producing basins discussed; indication of the case history location.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This section will describe the workflow applied to evaluate a nontraditional water source used as base component in a fracturing fluid (Fig. 2). The main focus of this section is to describe the type of tests performed for gelling systems (linear gel and crosslinked gel).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Workflow.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A hydration test was performed using a rotational viscometer, equipped with a R1B1 rotor-bob couette configuration (Fann-35) (Fig. 3A). Ther interim measurement shear rate of all the tests was 511 1/sec, with the preparation of the linear gels being performed using a constant speed blender-type mixer at 2,000 RPM. The pH of the water samples was adjusted to the desired level using a buffer (weak organic acid or potassium carbonate).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory equipment: (a) rotational viscometer for hydration test; (b) HPHT rheometer for rheology test; (c) specialized device for proppant transport evaluation used in a HPHT rheometer.

formatted-caption.caption-text: —Laboratory equipment: (a) rotational viscometer for hydration test; (b) HPHT rheometer for rheology test; (c) specialized device for proppant transport evaluation used in a HPHT rheometer.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: specialized device for proppant transport evaluation used in a HPHT rheometer

linkTarget.anchoringText: Initial tests were performed with sample 1 to evaluate the performance of a guar-borate fluid that used two crosslinkers: a primary-delayed (XBor-c) and a secondary-instant (XBor-b). Some adjustments to the concentration of these crosslinkers were made to obtain a fluid that met the requirement. Additional tests were performed at two lower temperatures (125°F and 100°F) to improve the breaking profile, thereby changing the crosslinkers and breakers. Information on these tests (A, B, and C) is presented in Table 4 and Fig. 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity profile developed in a HPHT rheometer.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity profile developed in a HPHT rheometer.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The completion was performed between February and March of 2014. The fourth fracture stages were performed in four days, with the main information for this treatment being presented in Table 5.Fig. 5 shows a panoramic view of the wellsite, Fig. 6 presents the treatment chart for the first frac stage. A total of 1.0 million of gallons of produced water were consumed throughout the entire treatment process, 49% of which comprised the gelling system and 30% was the crosslinked fluid (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Panoramic view of the fracturing equipment setup at the well location in the Golfo San Jorge basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Panoramic view of the fracturing equipment setup at the well location in the Golfo San Jorge basin.

A total of 1.0 million of gallons of produced water were consumed throughout the entire treatment process, 49% of which comprised the gelling system and 30% was the crosslinked fluid (Fig. 7).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Operational graph corresponding to pumping the first stage hydraulic fracture (hybrid design).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The completion was performed between February and March of 2014. The fourth fracture stages were performed in four days, with the main information for this treatment being presented in Table 5.Fig. 5 shows a panoramic view of the wellsite, Fig. 6 presents the treatment chart for the first frac stage. A total of 1.0 million of gallons of produced water were consumed throughout the entire treatment process, 49% of which comprised the gelling system and 30% was the crosslinked fluid (Fig. 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Total volume of produced water consumed by fracture fluid type during the stimulations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Total volume of produced water consumed by fracture fluid type during the stimulations.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 8 illustrates the rheology profile for these systems, in which two time intervals were evaluated: an early time (0 to 5 minutes) and an extended time (10 to 60 minutes). In the beginning, Fluids 2 and 3 presented a high viscosity peak, reflected mainly for the action of XBor-b (high-pH instant boron crosslinkers). These fluids have the highest pH of all systems tested. Fluids 1 and 4 presented lower values and in a similar order to the longer time interval. Additionally, these fluids demonstrated a lower pH for all the systems. For the second time interval evaluated, Fluids 1 and 3 showed a lower viscosity (average of 250 cp) than Fluids 2 and 4 for the same gel loading (25 ppt).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity profile for the evaluated fluid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity profile for the evaluated fluid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The objective for this part of the process was to validate the fluid selected under a variable shear test following the API RP 39 standard. This test was a longer stability test (120 minutes) performed at 140°F, showing a stable viscosity profile without any viscosity degradation/loss for the shear action (Fig. 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Shear variable test (API RP 39) for the selected fluid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shear variable test (API RP 39) for the selected fluid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The target for this stage was to perform a group of break tests at different temperatures to obtain a family of fluid formulations with several breaking times, as shown in Table 10 and Fig. 10. These formulations have been used in most of the treatments for both the conventional treatments (100%crosslinked) and the jobs using the hybrid design in vertical and horizontal wells. It is well established that for low temperatures, an expensive enzyme breaker is often applied. The breaker used for this fluid was an oxidizer, which was combined with a catalyst at 100°F to accelerate the breaking time. This breaker and catalyst did not negatively impact the cost of the fluid system.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Breaking test evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Breaking test evaluation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 11 presents a slurry-viscosity graph for Fluid 2, in which three periods of time can be identified. The initial period, from 0 to 60 minutes, is called the elastic transport region. During this time, the fluid showed excellent proppant transport capacity, as the proppant was suspended in the fluid. The settlement process began after this initial period, which was identified over a period of 20 minutes (from the 60- to 80-minute mark) and corresponded to the region of viscous settlement. This breaker action weakened the structure-based fracture fluid. Finally, between 80 and 175 minutes, only one proppant decanted, which shows the lack of system structure by the breaker action at that temperature. These tests demonstrated good proppant transport capacity for the evaluated fluid.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Proppant transport capacity evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant transport capacity evaluation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: During 2017 and the first four months of 2018, a total of 33 wells (5 horizontal and 28 vertical), with a total of 80 fracture stages, was completed. For these completions, a total of 4.8 million gallons of water were consumed, 4.7 million gallons of which were formation water (Fig. 12). Only six stages consumed fresh water; the remaining 74 stages were performed using formation water from conventional treatments (100% crosslinked). A detailed quality control plan has been executed for each operation to ensure the right properties and performance of the fluid.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Water consumption by water type.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water consumption by water type.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 13A and 13B present operations graphs for the first horizontal well program executed. This operation was scheduled to be performed in two days to comply with the logistics requirements for this region of southern Patagonia (volume of water and proppant). Fig. 14 illustrates the fracturing equipment setup on location.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13a

formatted-caption.caption-text: Operational graph; first day of operation (execution of four fracture stages).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Following the same analysis criteria applied previously (Austral Basin), Fig. 15 illustrates the rheology profile for these systems. The early time (0 to 5 minutes) showed a high viscosity peak for Fluids 1 and 2 in relation to XBor-a and XBor-b. These fluids demonstrate pH values between 8.6 and 9.0. Fluid 4 has lower values for this initial time. For the second time interval evaluated, Fluid 4 proved to be the most stable with a higher viscosity profile, followed by Fluid 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity profile for the evaluated fluid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity profile for the evaluated fluid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The selected fluid was tested under a variable shear test following standard, API RP 39. As required, a stability test of the fluid was performed at 100°F for 120 minutes, which resulted in a very good viscosity profile without any viscosity degradation/loss owing to shear (Fig. 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Shear variable test (API-39) for the selected fluid.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shear variable test (API-39) for the selected fluid.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 17 and 18 present the rheology profiles for the initial test and the second group using the temperature ramp. In the two cases (tests at 100°F and 75°F), when the second ramp began (60 minutes), a sudden viscosity loss was obtained, which showed a clear break profile with the same breaker concentration. The new Fluid 1 demonstrated less gel loading (20 ppt) and, thus, met the expectation for these tests.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Breaking test evaluation at 100°F.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Breaking test evaluation at 100°F.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figs. 17 and 18 present the rheology profiles for the initial test and the second group using the temperature ramp. In the two cases (tests at 100°F and 75°F), when the second ramp began (60 minutes), a sudden viscosity loss was obtained, which showed a clear break profile with the same breaker concentration. The new Fluid 1 demonstrated less gel loading (20 ppt) and, thus, met the expectation for these tests.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Breaking test evaluation at 75°F.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Breaking test evaluation at 75°F.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fig. 19 presents two tests for the Fluid 1 formulations at two different gel loadings. Three time intervals are shown in the slurry viscosity graph. The initial period from 0 to 60 minutes (first temperature ramp) is called the elastic transport region. During this interval of time, the fluid showed very good proppant transport capacity, as proppant was suspended in the fluid. The next time interval of 10 minutes, which occurred between the 60- and 70-minute mark, represents the settlement process. This second temperature ramp corresponds to the region of viscous settlement. This action by the breake

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Proppant transport capacity evaluation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proppant transport capacity evaluation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Between August and September of 2017, five wells were completed with a total of 16 fracture stages. The final fluid system used was Fluid 1 at 25 ppt throughout the entire job. During this operation, a total of 2.1 million gallons of produced water was consumed, 45% of which was used to prepare the tailored fracture fluid (Fig. 20). A detailed quality control plan was executed for each operation throughout the campaign, with no issues related to the fracture fluid. Fig. 21 presents a typical operation chart, and Fig. 22 shows a frac set on location.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Total volume of produced water consumed by type of fracture fluid during the campaign.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Total volume of produced water consumed by type of fracture fluid during the campaign.
